bnf

Class Tree<V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • bnf.Tree<V>

  • public class Tree<V>
extends java.lang.Object
    The Tree class represents a tree data structure that allows shared structure (nodes may have multiple parents in the tree as long as no looping occurs). This is a Generic class that allows any type of Object as the values of the nodes. Getters and setters for the node values and children are provided (getValue(), setValue(V), addChild(int, Tree, addChildren(Tree...), getChild(int), and getNumberOfChildren()). In addition, methods are provided to output the tree as a String (toString()) or via print (print()), and to parse a String description of the tree to a Tree object (parse()).
    Version:
    2/2/2013
    Author:
    Michael McLaughlin, mvm

    • Constructor Detail

      • Tree

        @SafeVarargs
public Tree(V value,
                Tree<V>... children)
     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Constructor for the Tree. Creates a new tree with the specified value and children. Checks for potential loops in creating the tree as specified and returns an Exception if one is found.
        Parameters:
        value - The value of the new tree.
        children - Children of the new tree in l-to-r order.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - Thrown if a loop would be created by this tree.

      • addChild

        public void addChild(int index,
            Tree<V> child)
              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                     java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
        Adds a single child tree to the tree at the given index. Checks for potential loops in adding the child to the tree as specified and returns an Exception if one is found.
        Parameters:
        index - The index at which to add the child.
        child - The tree to add as the child.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - Thrown if the child is null or would create a loop.
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - Thrown if the given index is less than zero or greater than the number of children.

      • addChildren

        public void addChildren(Tree<V>... children)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Adds one or more child trees to the tree in l-to-r order to the right of any existing children. Checks for potential loops in adding children to the tree as specified and returns an Exception if one is found.
        Parameters:
        children - The child trees to add to the parent tree.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If thrown due to a null child or potential loop, no children are added.

      • iterator

        Returns the iterator object for a tree's children.
        Returns:

      • parse

        public static Tree<java.lang.String> parse(java.lang.String treeDescription)
        Parses a String describing a tree into a Tree object. The String must start with the value of the root node of the tree. The children of each node are contained within parentheses. Example input: "value1(value2 value3(value4) value5(value6 value7))" becomes: 
                 value1
       /    |    \ 
 value2  value3  value5
            |     |    \
         value4 value6 value7
        Parameters:
        treeDescription - The String describing the desired tree.
        Returns:
        The Tree object described by the String.

      • print

        public void print()
        Prints a representation of the tree to the standard output stream. Trees are output in this format, where nodes at the same level in the tree are at the same level l-to-r: 
         value1
 |  value2
 |  value3
 |  |  value4
 |  |  |  value5
 |  value6
 |  |  value7
 |  |  value8

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Generates a String representation of a tree. Example - this tree generates the following String: Tree: 
                  one
        /     \
      two     three
            /       \  
         four       five
                  /  |  \
               six seven eight
        Output String: 
        one(two three(four five(six seven eight)))
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Tests for equality between this tree and another object. Returns true if: -The object is a Tree
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to test for equality.
        Returns:
        True if the trees are identical.
